s0001.literal: Gaozu was a person from Zhongyang Village, Fengyi Township, Pei County, and his surname was Liu.
s0001.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu hailed from Zhongyang Village in Fengyi Township, Pei County, and bore the surname Liu.

s0002.literal: His mother once rested by the bank of Daze Marsh, and dreamed that she encountered a god.
s0002.idiomatic: His mother once rested by the shore of Daze Marsh and dreamt of meeting a divine being.

s0003.literal: At that time there was thunder and lightning, darkness and obscurity; his father Taigong went to look, and then saw two dragons mating above.
s0003.idiomatic: Thunder crashed and lightning flashed in the darkened heavens; his father Taigong went to investigate and witnessed two dragons entwined above.

s0004.literal: Soon after she became pregnant, and then gave birth to Gaozu.
s0004.idiomatic: She soon conceived and thereafter bore Emperor Gaozu.

s0005.literal: 高祖為人，隆準而龍顏，美須髯，左股有七十二黑子。
s0005.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu had a prominent nose and dragon-like features, beautiful whiskers and beard, and seventy-two black moles on his left thigh.

s0006.literal: 仁而愛人，喜施，意豁如也。
s0006.idiomatic: He was benevolent and loved people, enjoyed giving charity, and had an open-hearted disposition.

s0007.literal: 常有大度，不事家人生產作業。
s0007.idiomatic: He always had great generosity of spirit and did not engage in the family's farming and labor.

s0008.literal: 及壯，學書不成，去；學劍，又不成。
s0008.idiomatic: When he grew to adulthood, he studied writing but did not succeed, so he left; he studied swordsmanship, but again did not succeed.

s0009.idiomatic: He sighed and said, 'Will the paths of scholarship and swordsmanship ultimately lead nowhere?'

s0010.literal: 及見秦皇帝，車騎眾，覺其異，乃歎曰：「嗟乎，大丈夫當如此也！」
s0010.idiomatic: When he saw the Qin emperor with his many chariots and cavalry, he realized how extraordinary it was, and sighed, 'Alas, this is how a great man should be!'

s0011.literal: 單父人呂公善沛令，避仇，從之客，因家焉。
s0011.idiomatic: Lü Gong from Shanfu was friendly with the magistrate of Pei; to avoid his enemies, he became a guest there and settled his family.

s0012.literal: 呂公女乃呂后也，生孝惠、魯元公主。
s0012.idiomatic: Lü Gong's daughter was Empress Lü, who gave birth to Emperor Hui and Princess Lu Yuan.

s0013.literal: 及長，家貧，呂公女配高祖，生惠帝、魯元。
s0013.idiomatic: When she grew up, the family was poor; Lü Gong's daughter was married to Gaozu and bore Emperor Hui and Lu Yuan.

s0014.literal: 沛中子弟或聞其異，皆嘲笑之。
s0014.idiomatic: Some of the young men of Pei heard of his unusual nature and all mocked and laughed at him.

s0015.literal: 高祖每酤留飲，酒讎數倍。
s0015.idiomatic: Whenever Gaozu bought wine to drink, the tavern keeper charged him several times the amount.

s0016.literal: 及見怪，歲竟，此兩家常折券棄責。
s0016.idiomatic: When they saw that he was unusual, at the end of each year these two families would tear up the debt contracts and forgive his obligations.

s0017.literal: 高祖怪之，問曰：「何故而然？」
s0017.idiomatic: Gaozu was puzzled by this and asked, 'Why do you do this?'

s0018.literal: 兩家曰：「君何言之闇也！長者千金，子孫息，君衣帛，買爵，君何言之闇也！」
s0018.idiomatic: The two families said, 'How can you speak so ignorantly! When the elders give a thousand pieces of gold, their descendants multiply; you wear silk clothes and buy official ranks—how can you speak so ignorantly!'

s0019.literal: 高祖豁達大度，聞之，輒喜，自知者少。
s0019.idiomatic: Gaozu was broad-minded and magnanimous; hearing this, he was immediately pleased, realizing that few understood him.

s0020.literal: 高祖常繇咸陽，縶亭長，灞上亭。
s0020.idiomatic: Gaozu often traveled the corvée road to Xianyang, stopping at the pavilion chief's station at Ba Terrace.

s0021.literal: 亭長妻有從者，醉酒，夜徑澤中，行徑澤中。
s0021.idiomatic: The pavilion chief had a wife with attendants; getting drunk on wine, they traveled at night through the marshes, going through the marshes.

s0022.literal: 令一人先行，前者還報曰：「前有大蛇當徑，願還。」
s0022.idiomatic: He ordered one person to go ahead; the one who went ahead returned and reported: 'There is a large snake blocking the path ahead; I wish to turn back.'

s0023.idiomatic: Gaozu was drunk and said, 'A brave man walks forward—what is there to fear!'

s0024.literal: 乃前，拔劍擊斬蛇，徑分為兩。
s0024.idiomatic: He went forward, drew his sword, and struck down the snake, splitting it into two parts along the path.

s0025.idiomatic: He walked along the path to where the snake had been and lay down drunk.

s0026.literal: 後人來至蛇所，有一老嫗夜哭。
s0026.idiomatic: Later, people came to where the snake was, and there was an old woman crying at night.

s0027.literal: 人問何哭，嫗曰：「人殺吾子，故哭之。」
s0027.idiomatic: People asked why she was crying; the old woman said, 'Someone killed my son, so I cry for him.'

s0028.idiomatic: The people said, 'Old woman's son, why was he killed?'

s0029.literal: 嫗曰：「吾子，白帝子也，化為蛇，當徑，今為赤帝子斬之，故哭。」
s0029.idiomatic: The old woman said, 'My son is the son of the White Emperor; he transformed into a snake to block the path, but now he has been slain by the son of the Red Emperor, so I cry.'

s0030.literal: 人以嫗為不誠，欲笞之；嫗因忽不見。
s0030.idiomatic: The people considered the old woman dishonest and wanted to beat her; but the old woman suddenly disappeared.

s0031.idiomatic: Later, when people arrived, Gaozu awoke and told them about it.

s0032.idiomatic: Gaozu was secretly pleased in his heart and felt self-confident.

s0033.idiomatic: His followers grew increasingly in awe of him.

s0034.literal: 秦始皇帝常曰：「東南有天子氣。」
s0034.idiomatic: Qin Shihuang often said, 'There is imperial aura in the southeast.'

s0035.idiomatic: Therefore he traveled east to suppress it.

s0036.literal: 高祖以亭長為縣送徒騉山，徒多道亡。
s0036.idiomatic: Gaozu, as pavilion chief, escorted convicts from the county to Mount Li; many convicts escaped along the way.

s0037.literal: 自度比至皆亡之，到豐西澤中，止飲，夜乃解縱所送徒。
s0037.idiomatic: He estimated that by the time they arrived, all would have escaped; when they reached the western marshes of Feng, he stopped for a drink, and at night released all the convicts he was escorting.

s0038.literal: 曰：「公等皆去，吾亦從此逝矣！」
s0038.idiomatic: He said, 'You all go; I too will depart from here!'

s0039.literal: 徒中壯士願從者十餘人。
s0039.idiomatic: Among the convicts, about ten strong men wished to follow him.

s0040.literal: 高祖被酒，夜徑澤中，令一人行前。
s0040.idiomatic: Gaozu was drunk and traveled through the marshes at night, ordering one person to go ahead.

s0041.literal: 行前者還報曰：「前有大蛇當徑，願還。」
s0041.idiomatic: The one who went ahead returned and reported: 'There is a large snake blocking the path ahead; I wish to turn back.'

s0042.idiomatic: Gaozu was drunk and said, 'A brave man walks forward—what is there to fear!'

s0043.idiomatic: He went forward, drew his sword, and struck down the snake.

s0044.idiomatic: Gaozu then proceeded forward and arrived at Xianyang.

s0045.literal: 諸客遂追隨，高祖以辭去。
s0045.idiomatic: The various guests then followed him; Gaozu left with excuses.

s0046.literal: 沛公奉項梁客軍，遮擊秦軍於東阿。
s0046.idiomatic: Prince Pei served under Xiang Liang's guest army and ambushed Qin forces at Dong'a.

s0047.literal: 戰不利，項梁再破秦軍於東阿。
s0047.idiomatic: The battle went unfavorably; Xiang Liang again defeated the Qin army at Dong'a.

s0048.literal: 沛公引兵西，遇彭越昌邑。
s0048.idiomatic: Prince Pei led his troops west and encountered Peng Yue at Changyi.

s0049.literal: 項籍已殺宋義，引兵而西。
s0049.idiomatic: Xiang Ji had already killed Song Yi and led his troops west.

s0050.literal: 漢王之國，項王使卒三萬人從。
s0050.idiomatic: When the Han King went to his fief, Xiang Wang sent thirty thousand soldiers to follow him.
